metadata.case_name: Raja Rajinder Chand v. Defendants (Adna Maliks)

facts.text: Plaintiff Raja Rajinder Chand, superior landlord (alamalik) of Nadaun Jagir in Kangra district, brought six suits in Court of Subordinate Judge, 4th Class, Kangra in 1940 (Suits Nos. 544, 548, 545, 547, 546, 549) for declaration of ownership of all pine (chil-pinus longifolia) trees on lands of defendants, permanent injunction against interference, and damages for tapping from March 24, 1940.
Defendants, adna maliks (inferior landlords), pleaded ownership and possession of lands and trees thereon; plaintiff had no right and never exercised possession.
Subordinate Judge held plaintiff failed to prove ownership, suits barred by limitation, dismissed suits but noted small damages if ownership proved.
District Judge, Hoshiarpur, reversed on ownership and limitation, accepted damages finding, allowed appeals, granted declaration, injunction, damages in four suits.
Punjab High Court reversed District Judge on ownership (agreed with Subordinate Judge), agreed on limitation, allowed second appeals, dismissed suits; granted certificate under ss. 109, 110 CPC.
Suit lands in Badhog and Jasai tappas within Nadaun Jagir, Kangra district; proprietary and cultivated lands of adna maliks.
Last independent ruler of Kangra: Raja Sansar Chand (died 1824), Katoch Rajput; legitimate son Raja Anirudh Chand; illegitimate son Raja Jodhbir Chand by Gaddi woman.
Kangra conquered by Sikhs under Maharaja Ranjit Singh; Jodhbir Chand created Raja, granted Nadaun Jagir; by 1827-28 Kangra annexed to Sikh kingdom.
Appellant Raja Rajinder Chand is fourth in direct lineal descent from Raja Jodhbir Chand.
British occupation after Sikh wars (1846, 1848); Jodhbir Chand loyal, obtained Sanad October 11, 1848 renewing earlier 1846 Sanad.

Sanad granted Jagir of Nadaun (tappas, villages, Jama Rs. 26,270/10/3) in perpetuity to Raja Jodhbir Chand and male legitimate descendants; conditions: no criminal jurisdiction, revenue only per British rules, no mahsul/octroi/excise, etc.
Settlements: Barnes (1850-52, no Nadaun ops); Lyall (1865-72, no Nadaun); O'Brien/Anderson (1892-93 Wajib-ul-arz Ex.P-5); Anderson (1899-1900 Ex.P-6); Middleton/Shuttleworth (1910-15 Ex.P-4).
Ala-malik: superior proprietor (Raja); adna-malik: inferior proprietor (occupants with long possession).
Wajib-ul-arz 1892-93 (Ex.P-5, para 11): Owners no right to pine trees; Government right as per Forest Settlement Report para 78.
Wajib-ul-arz 1899-1900 (Ex.P-6): Except chil trees, all trees in khata property of owner; chil trees property of Raja.
Wajib-ul-arz 1910-15 (Ex.P-4): Similar to Ex.P-6, excepting some proprietary lands held Government property.
Respondents not contesting limitation finding; suits within time.
Ex.P-2 (1886): Some adna maliks complained Rajas men cut chil trees on their lands.

legal_issues.text: Whether all pine trees standing on suit lands (proprietary/cultivated lands of adna maliks) are property of plaintiff (alamalik).

petitioner_arguments.text: Ownership based on: (1) Ancestors (independent Kangra rulers) owned land/trees, granted land to adna maliks' ancestors retaining pine trees; (2) Post-conquest, British rights assigned to Raja Jodhbir Chand via Sanad; (3) Vouchsafed by Wajib-ul-arz entries (1892-93,1899-1900,1910-15) and judicial decisions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kangra District Gazetteer; Sanad 1848; Wajib-ul-arz as record-of-rights

respondent_arguments.text: Defendants own lands/trees in possession; plaintiff no right or possession.
Wajib-ul-arz entries relate to waste/nautor lands only, authority doubtful; no surrender of sovereign right.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected ground 1: Appellant not successor to sovereign rights of independent Katoch rulers (illegitimate descent, annexation by Sikhs/British); Jodhbir Chand mere grantee of revenue.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sovereign rights passed to Sikhs then British; grantee position lower.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected ground 2: Sanad 1848 construed strictly for sovereign; grants revenue (Jama) only, no mention of trees/royal rights; conditions limit to revenue per British rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No express grant of pine trees on proprietary lands.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected ground 3: Wajib-ul-arz entries (Exs.P-4,5,6) not creating title/surrender sovereign right; record customs only, confused scope (waste vs proprietary), no unambiguous relinquishment; Jamabandis no restriction; oral/judgments weak.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption displaced; entries opinions, not binding on civil courts.

holdings.text: Appellant failed to establish ownership right to pine trees on proprietary/cultivated lands of adna maliks.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vajesingji Joravarsingji v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State: rights only as recognised by new sovereign.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajah Venkata Narasimha Appa Row Bahadur v. Rajah Narayya Appa Row Bahadur
precedents_cited.relevance: Revenue authorities' views on grant construction not binding civil courts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dakas Khan v. Ghulam Kasim Khan

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887
statutes_cited.relevance: Wajib-ul-arz part of record-of-rights; presumption of truth.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the six appeals, upheld High Court dismissal of suits, holding appellant failed to prove ownership of pine trees; no order as to costs in any court due to confusion from Wajib-ul-arz entries.
outcome.costs: No order for costs in High Court or courts below.

key_quotes.text: "The short but important question which arises in these appeals is whether the present appellant has been able to establish his right to all pine chil trees standing on the suit lands of the defendants."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We agree therefore with the High Court that on a true and proper construction of the Sanad, it is impossible to spell out of its terms a grant in favour of Raja Jodhbir Chand of the right to all pine trees on cultivated and proprietary lands."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "...the entries in the Wajib-ul-arz... do not and cannot show any existing custom of the village, the right being a sovereign right nor do they show in unambiguous terms that the sovereign right was surrendered or relinquished in favour of the Raja."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Wajib-ul-arz as proof of title.
